description: From Middle English bodi, bodiȝ, from Old English bodiġ (“body, trunk, chest, torso, height, stature”), from Proto-West Germanic *bodag (“body, trunk”), from Proto-Indo-European *bʰewdʰ- (“to be awake, observe”).

entries.meaning: The physical structure of a human or animal seen as one single organism. [from 9th c.]
examples: I saw them walking from a distance, their bodies strangely angular in the dawn light.

entries.meaning: The fleshly or corporeal nature of a human, as opposed to the spirit or soul. [from 13th c.]
examples: The body is driven by desires, but the soul is at peace.

entries.meaning: A corpse. [from 13th c.]
examples: Her body was found at four o'clock, just two hours after the murder.

entries.meaning: (archaic or informal except in compounds) A person. [from 13th c.]
examples: Indeed, if it belonged to a poor body, it would be another thing; but so great a lady, to be sure, can never want it  […]

entries.meaning: (sociology) A human being, regarded as marginalized or oppressed.
examples: This, of course, was not about the State, but it was certainly an invasion: black bodies acting out in a public domain circumscribed by a racist culture. The Garvey movement presents an example of black bodies transgressing racialized spatial boundaries.

entries.meaning: The torso, the main structure of a human or animal frame excluding the extremities (limbs, head, tail). [from 9th c.]
examples: The boxer took a blow to the body.

entries.meaning: The largest or most important part of anything, as distinct from its appendages or accessories. [from 11th c.]
examples: The bumpers and front tyres were ruined, but the body of the car was in remarkable shape.

entries.meaning: (archaic) The section of a dress extending from the neck to the waist, excluding the arms. [from 16th c.]
examples: Penny was in the scullery, pressing the body of her new dress.

entries.meaning: The content of a letter, message, or other printed or electronic document, as distinct from signatures, salutations, headers, and so on. [from 17th c.]
A bodysuit. [from 19th c.]
(programming) The code of a subroutine, contrasted to its signature and parameters. [from 20th c.]
examples: In many programming languages, the method body is enclosed in braces.

entries.meaning: A group of people having a common purpose or opinion; a mass. [from 16th c.]
examples: I was escorted from the building by a body of armed security guards.

entries.meaning: An organisation, company or other authoritative group. [from 17th c.]
examples: The local train operating company is the managing body for this section of track.

entries.meaning: A unified collection of details, knowledge or information. [from 17th c.]
examples: We have now amassed a body of evidence which points to one conclusion.

entries.meaning: Any physical object or material thing. [from 14th c.]
examples: All bodies are held together by internal forces.

entries.meaning: (uncountable) Substance; physical presence. [from 17th c.]
examples: We have given body to what was just a vague idea.

entries.meaning: (uncountable) Comparative viscosity, solidity or substance (in wine, colours etc.). [from 17th c.]
examples: The red wine, sadly, lacked body.

entries.meaning: An agglomeration of some substance, especially one that would be otherwise uncountable.
examples: In a gentle breeze, the whole body of air, as far as the breeze extends, moves at the rate of seven or eight miles an hour; in a high wind, at the rate of seventy, eighty, or an hundred miles an hour  […]

entries.meaning: (printing) The shank of a type, or the depth of the shank (by which the size is indicated).
examples: a nonpareil face on an agate body

entries.meaning: (geometry) A three-dimensional object, such as a cube or cone.

verbs.description: body (third-person singular simple present bodies, present participle bodying, simple past and past participle bodied)

entries.meaning: To give body or shape to something.
To construct the bodywork of a car.
(transitive) To embody.
(transitive, slang, African-American Vernacular) To murder someone.
(transitive, slang, African-American Vernacular, by extension) To utterly defeat someone.
(transitive, slang, video games) to hard counter a particular character build or play style.  Frequently used in the passive voice form, get bodied by.
